The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to other foundational problems in mathematics. However, the mathematical structure of Hilbert space, on which the category of operators on it is built, is not directly accessible to intuition. This paper provides a set of axioms for the category of continuous linear operators on Hilbert space, which are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are then shown to be equivalent to the existence of a universal property for this category. This provides a mathematical foundation for the reconstruction of quantum mechanics from the category of Hilbert spaces and continuous operators on it. The axioms are also shown to be consistent with the standard mathematical theory of operator algebras. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the cargo-receptor complex. This results in the inhibition of STAT1 and STAT2 transcriptional activity. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere in the world, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. This study also shows that the instability of global maize production will increase with warming, and that the instability of global grain trade will increase with the instability of global maize production. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they are concerned about accessing the CARES Act loans. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will need to be expanded to provide grants rather than loans to avoid exacerbating the financial distress of small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the total amount of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The ability to increase the number of offspring produced in a given period is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we examine the factors that influence this reproductive output. We find that the most important factor is the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy can come from the mother’s own body (allocare) or from the environment (provisioning). The amount of energy available to the mother is strongly influenced by the state of the mother’s body, which is in turn influenced by the amount of energy available to the mother. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals and other organisms. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebellar cortex. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. The pathological hallmark of MSA is the loss of oligodendrocytes, which are the main producers of myelin in the central nervous system. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and inform public health policy. The API provides data on cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as mobility, online search trends, and deidentified medical claims data. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in potassium channels. The structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which is based on the communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural basis for the design of selective K+ channel modulators.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and other microorganisms that play important roles in the health of the animal and the plant. The gut microbiome of herbivores is often dominated by a few species, and the composition of the microbiome is thought to be important for the health of the animal. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, some of which could be used as antimicrobials. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a promising source of natural products for the development of new antibiotics. This work also highlights the potential of using 'omics' approaches to investigate the potential of fungi to synthesize natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study highlights the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and points to a potential role for anxiety in the etiology of social disorders.

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is essential for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the restricted material choices and the lack of understanding of the underlying deformation mechanisms. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses. The proposed strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are digitally designed and manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The digitally designed structures are then physically realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and physical realization strategy can be utilized to design and manufacture mechanical devices with highly complex and programmable behaviors for a wide range of applications. This work can also inspire the design of other complex systems with desired behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein is a key component of this pathway. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 can affect the expression of the hemoglobin genes in human erythroid cells. The results suggest that the heterochronous regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans is mediated by the IGF2BP1 protein.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by activation of the mTORC1-SREBP1-SCD1 pathway, which promotes lipogenesis and ferroptosis resistance. In preclinical models, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression. These findings suggest that the combination of ferroptosis induction with mTORC1 inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells, which promotes vascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in clinical practice. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP did halt clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems on federal land may be counterproductive to the conservation of older-forest–associated birds. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will require a continued focus on the science of forest management and adaptive management.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge in the medical field. The main reason for this is the emergence of antibiotic resistance in bacteria. Therefore, the rational design of new antibiotics is an important tool to combat this problem. In this study, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of the designed compounds. The predicted best compound was synthesized and tested in vitro and in vivo. The results show that the designed compound is more active than the current standard of care, telithromycin, and has a better safety profile. The design strategy presented in this study can be used to develop new antibiotics with improved properties. This will help to keep pace with the evolution of antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, making it easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on a simple set of operations that can be easily implemented, trained, and applied in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful for many image-processing problems.

Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with a number of negative health consequences, including reduced sleep duration and quality, reduced daytime alertness, and an increased risk of accidents. The mechanisms underlying these effects are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin secretion, delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely to be mediated by the light emitted by the electronic device.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 100-m drop in global temperature that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the ejecta spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is not yet fully understood. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, which are not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adulthood is a more relevant model for the study of autoimmunity.

The order Coleoptera (beetles) is arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding (herbivory) on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, and to identify the genes that enabled the evolution of their unique feeding habits. We found that the evolution of herbivory in beetles was driven by the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These genes were acquired multiple times, and independently, by beetles, and may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-SeekBar virus variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is associated with a twofold decreased risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type of the central nervous system. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased risk of AD in APOE4 homozygotes.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km, which is the deepest part of the Earth. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the crystallization process of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. This study shows that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the crystallization of ordinary minerals. This study provides a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core and the crystallization process of the Earth. It also provides a new perspective for understanding the origin of the Earth's magnetic field. (Show more)

The use of marijuana is widespread, and the drug is increasingly available in the form of “medical” marijuana. The effects of marijuana on the brain are poorly understood, and the drug’s effects on the brain are likely to be complex. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is blunted in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to have negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. The blunted brain reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers may contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

The brain’s processing of language is the most complex cognitive process we know of. How it works is a mystery, in part because of the difficulty of studying it in action. Here we show that deep learning models, which excel at pattern recognition, can predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences with strong accuracy and generalizability. This suggests that predictive processing may be a fundamental organizing principle of the language comprehension mechanism in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear why DL works, and why it is so successful. In this paper, we show that the success of DL is due to the existence of stable neural networks (NNs). We prove that there exist stable NNs that can approximate any given function with a given accuracy. We also prove that there exist unstable NNs that cannot approximate any given function with a given accuracy. These results imply a classification theory of stability of NNs, which can be used to understand the success of DL. Moreover, we introduce a fast and stable algorithm for solving inverse problems, which can be used to understand the success of DL in solving inverse problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community has been slow to recognize the many ways in which the pandemic is a product of scientific failures. One of the most prominent is the failure to understand exponential growth. This failure is often attributed to a classic experiment published 45 years ago. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed in multiple ways, and that the conclusion is not supported by the data. We discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human behavior, and for the role of science in society.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause infection of the peripheral nerves and the central nervous system, respectively. The two species are very similar, but the former is the cause of the more common disease, while the latter is associated with a rare, chronic, and fatal disease known as lepromatous leprosy. In this study, we sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species have retained many of the same genes, despite having diverged from a common ancestor approximately 14 million years ago. This suggests that the two species are remarkably conserved and that the differences between them are likely to be the result of recent evolution. This study may help to explain the differences between the two diseases. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the Heisenberg spin chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, as it provides a complete description of the entanglement evolution in the space–time scaling limit.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in more than 200 million cases and over 4.3 million deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This vaccine is expensive, and its production is limited by the need for ultracold storage. In this study, we describe a vaccine that is easy to produce, can be stored at room temperature, and is highly protective against COVID-19. This vaccine is based on a modified version of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is easy to grow in culture, and the vaccine strain is highly attenuated in vivo. This vaccine is a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was the longest and most devastating of the four pandemics of Yersinia pestis. The transmission of plague by rats was widely accepted as the main cause of the epidemics. However, the role of human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, has been neglected. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for understanding the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague in the past and today.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal behavior. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only driver of cognitive evolution. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also shaped by the evolution of the number of neurons. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only shaped by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the other major target of this family of molecular chaperones. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the major structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled by a family of proteins. These proteins are important regulators of cell motility and shape. The proteins of this family are named actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family, because they can cause the disassembly of actin filaments. We show that the proteins of this family can also sever actin filaments. We show that the severing of filaments is enhanced by a mechanical torque that is generated by the proteins when they bind to filaments. This mechanism is important for cells, because it allows the proteins to sever highly connected filament networks, which are found in the cytoskeleton.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing, greater hunger, and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The findings also suggest that the brain may be a target for the effects of sweeteners on feeding behavior. The results may have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for the development of strategies to reduce the consumption of these beverages.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and the majority of nonprotein-coding RNAs are not even transcribed from DNA. The vast majority of RNAs are not even translated into proteins. The RNA world is a reality in the cell, and the study of RNAs is a critical component of understanding the molecular basis of life. This study focuses on one of the most common modifications found in RNA, pseudouridine (Ψ), and its impact on protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA (mRNA) can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This study adds to the growing appreciation that the ribosome can encounter RNA modifications and make changes to protein synthesis. The study of RNA modifications is critical to understanding the function of RNA in cells. (Show more)

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. (Show more)

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of this infection. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human body is unknown. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus replicate more efficiently at the temperature found in the nasal cavity than at the temperature of the human body. This difference in temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings may help to explain the preference of rhinovirus for the nasal cavity. (Show more)

The ability to sense the environment is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In bacteria, this process is often used to regulate the expression of virulence factors, which are essential for pathogenicity. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This process is essential for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for surface attachment. This mechanism is likely to be used by other bacteria to sense the environment and may be important for the regulation of virulence.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals is a major concern, as it may lead to the emergence of new variants that are more transmissible and/or resistant to current vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a free-living animal species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to monitor the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to mitigate the risk of spillover events and the emergence of new variants that may evade current control measures. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The problems associated with dams are well known, but the industry continues to build them. This paper examines the problems associated with large dams and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary focus of current research. However, the immune response in AD is complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in AD, even in the absence of Aβ plaques. This finding is significant because it suggests that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be the primary cause of the earliest inflammatory events in AD. This may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to prevent the development of AD.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing these caps, RppH, preferentially degrades Np4-capped RNAs over their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts. This preference is due to the unusual manner in which Np4-capped RNAs bind to the active site of RppH, positioning the δ-phosphate for attack by the enzyme. The differential impact of RppH on the rates at which capped and uncapped RNAs are degraded could have important implications for the reprogramming of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are not fully understood. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine deprivation is a common mechanism involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We also show that increasing arginine availability can restore T cell function and proliferation, decrease lymphopenia, and reduce the expansion of Treg and MDSCs, which are associated with poor clinical outcomes. These results suggest that arginine supplementation could be a promising strategy to improve the clinical outcomes of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to its original state in a time that is proportional to the power of the system size. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, earthquakes, and neural networks. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum computing, photonics, and energy storage. However, its properties are difficult to control and tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, which can be used to control its properties. This work provides a new route to control the properties of diamond, which can be used to tailor its properties for applications. This work also demonstrates the potential of machine learning to predict the properties of materials. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of fungicides. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a unique antifungal peptide from the nodules of a model legume, Medicago truncatula. This peptide is structurally unique and exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of this peptide was studied using a combination of structural, biochemical, and microscopy techniques. The results provide insights into the mode of action of this peptide and pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also highlights the potential of the model legume Medicago truncatula as a source of novel antimicrobial peptides. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female interface is dynamic, with multiple proteins being transferred between the sexes. We also show that the female reproductive tract is a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. The most common disorder of VWF is von Willebrand disease (VWD), which is caused by mutations in the gene that encodes VWF. We show that mutations in VWF cause the disorder by altering the force dependence of the binding reaction. This provides a mechanism for understanding the disorder and for developing new therapies.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 100 gigabases of viral sequence. The study also provides a resource for the study of virus–disease associations, with over 2,200 strong associations. This resource will be useful for the study of the human virome, and for the study of virus–disease associations.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is difficult to be observed simultaneously in space and time. This study introduces a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The dual-FOV HSRL is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This study provides a new way to observe the ACI process. It is expected to be widely used in the future.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life, as well as for the design of sustainable societies. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been inferred from isotopic data to have decreased over geological time, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. The activation and deactivation of ion channels are controlled by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the mechanism of the BK channel’s normal closing and its physiological roles. (Show more)

The malaria parasite is a master of host cell invasion, a process that is critical to the development of the parasite within the host. The invasion process is complex, involving a number of parasite proteins, but the role of the host cell in the process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that the invasion process is a balance between host and parasite cell physical forces, rather than a simple competition between parasite proteins. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for the control of malaria.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum computing, photonics, and energy storage. However, its properties are difficult to control and tune. Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of low humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza virus transmission and disease burden. They also provide a rationale for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does this remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. We also show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a word list with a similar increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to arbitrary linguistic objects. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to build syntactic structures. This operation may be implemented by a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

The pathway is regulated by the degradation of β-catenin, which is dependent on the presence of Wnt ligands and the activity of the Axin proteins. We show here that the two Axin proteins are regulated differently, and that this difference is important for the regulation of the pathway in different tissues.

The ability of bacteria to fix atmospheric nitrogen is a key process in the evolution of life on Earth. The ability of plants to induce this process in their symbiotic bacteria is a key process in the evolution of agriculture. We have developed a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant, and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to sustainably deliver biologically fixed nitrogen in agriculture. This work also represents a key step toward the development of synthetic nitrogen fixation systems for use in space and other environments where the availability of nitrogen is a limiting factor. The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate, and the causes of this deforestation are not well understood. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts to communities and training and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated, but the effects are imprecisely estimated. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than previously thought, and that the climate benefits are even larger. This is because air pollution and climate change are linked, and because aerosols mask the warming caused by greenhouse gases. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This would be a major challenge for the global community, but it is necessary to save millions of lives and to avoid the worst effects of climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many LMICs have limited access to vaccines. The development of a vaccine that is easy to manufacture and can be produced at scale is critical to global access. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD that is easy to manufacture, has high affinity for ACE2, and can be used to construct a VLP vaccine. This engineered RBD may be used to design a vaccine that can be manufactured globally and distributed to LMICs.

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are expressed in the developing nervous system and are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that the loss of DrLtk and DrALK causes distinct patterns of iridophore loss in the zebrafish. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. This study provides a link between the human ALKALs and the development of the zebrafish pigment cells. This knowledge will be useful for understanding the function of the ALKALs in the development of other tissues and for the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The timing of this event is still debated, and the available evidence is limited to a few ancient genomes. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time period for the evolution of the plague pathogen. Our results show that the plague pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps before it became a human pathogen, and that it rapidly spread across Eurasia. These data provide insights into the early evolution of the plague pathogen and its adaptation to its new host. They also reveal the importance of the flea in the spread of plague. This study highlights the importance of ancient genome analysis in understanding the origins of human pathogens. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The agricultural intensification of grasslands has led to massive emissions of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. This study shows that soil health management practices can mitigate this trend. We found that soil health management practices that minimize soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase soil organic carbon (SOC) storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral fraction. These practices also increase the efficiency of soil microbes in using carbon for growth. The results of this study highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a climate-smart agricultural solution. This study also highlights the importance of soil health management practices in the global effort to mitigate climate change. (Show more)

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is often an important factor in the success of pollination, as it is often correlated with the availability of light for pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also show that the same alkaloid is produced by the distantly related plant Jaltomata herrerae, which is visited by hummingbirds. The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped this structure are not fully understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from the late 5th/early 6th century AD from present-day Bavaria, southern Germany. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in humans has caused ∼36% fatality in infected patients. The virus is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for early detection of emerging and reemerging pathogens, and for the rapid deployment of public health response. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA polymerases, but the activity of such enzymes is limited to a few specific reactions. Here, we report the design, construction, and characterization of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 to 15 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients were identified. The results showed that the immune characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were similar to those of patients with other severe and critical diseases, and the immune characteristics of these patients were similar to those of patients with other severe and critical diseases. The results also showed that tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess can be toxic. The ability of fungi to sequester copper into specialized compartments and to regulate intracellular copper levels is poorly understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The copper-chelating properties of xan BGC isocyanide products were demonstrated in a range of fungal pathogens, including Candida species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and Aspergillus niger, and in bacteria. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal interactions with other microbes. (Show more)
