Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new frost regimes. We also show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is highly correlated with the geographic distribution of tree species, and that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the geographic distribution of frost damage. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of two transcription factors, T-bet and the Stat4 transcription factor. Moreover, we show that the development of Th17 cells can be blocked by the absence of the Stat4 transcription factor. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for our understanding of the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and for the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The development of disease models is essential for understanding the mechanisms of disease and for the development of new therapies. Here we describe a method to rapidly produce human astrocytes from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study the mechanisms of disease and to screen for new therapies. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of new therapies in ALS.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now demonstrate that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota to more efficiently colonize the tick. We show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. We also show that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, altering the permeability of the gut and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod vector. It also provides a potential target for the development of new strategies to control the spread of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail (pygostylians) provides new information about the origin of the modern avian tail and its early evolution. The new taxon, Jinguofortis, is an important addition to the known diversity of early pygostylians, which obscure our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of its components. In this paper, we show that one of the components, the stratospheric water vapor, has a significant impact on the climate system.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of mechanisms to avoid predation, including color patterns that mimic the background of their environment. In this study, we show that the occurrence of high biliverdin concentrations in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also introduces a new mechanism for the evolution of color patterns. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer cells are often exposed to hypoxia, which is associated with poor prognosis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces breast cancer cells to express a breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype, which is associated with increased expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG. We also show that this effect is mediated by hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-dependent expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5). Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was often called “uterine vellum,” but the source of this material has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a method that can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of the parchment used to make the first printed books. The results suggest that the source of the parchment was not limited to abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China. The age model is based on the age of five volcanic ash beds, which are used to define a precise age range for the extinction and recovery. The age model is used to evaluate the timing of the carbon cycle reorganization and the rate of recovery. The results are used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The results are also used to evaluate the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in the intestine and its potential as a therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the spike protein of currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutation leads to a range of more open conformations. These open conformations may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent viral membrane fusion.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even for finite games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical behavior of atoms is a fundamental property of matter, and it is the basis of all chemistry. The chemical properties of atoms are determined by the electronic structure of the atom, which is in turn determined by the atomic structure of the atom. The atomic structure of an atom is determined by the nuclear charge and the electronic structure of the atom, which is in turn determined by the electronic structure of the atom. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be predicted as a function of pressure, and that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict the chemical behavior of compounds. This is a fundamental result, and it has implications for the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the carbon cycle is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the impact of climate change on wildfires, potentially slowing global warming. This is because fires release carbon from the terrestrial ecosystem, which can offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gases. However, the risk of more extreme fires is also highlighted, which could have negative consequences for other ecosystem functions. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the impact of climate change on fire regimes. This will be critical for understanding the impact of climate change on the carbon cycle and the role of fire in the global carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a symbiosis. We also show that the provision of this glycan is restricted to a specific time of day, which is linked to the maturation of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. Finally, the catabolism of this glycan is also required for the periodic acidification of the host epithelium, which is required for the activity of the symbiont. This glycan may therefore be used as a tool to understand the regulation of the activities of other symbioses. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the volume of text is growing exponentially. We need methods to identify latent patterns in text data. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward a more nuanced understanding of the content of text data.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This study shows that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were the cause of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results provide evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe, which were the source of the disease in the local population. This study also shows that the Black Death was not a single event, but rather a series of events, each with its own unique characteristics. The results of this study have implications for our understanding of the history of the Black Death and the spread of infectious diseases in general.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease of the sea stars (asteroids) that has been observed in at least 20 species along the Pacific coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the tissues and has led to the mass mortality of millions of animals. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the sea stars. The virus is also present in the plankton and sediments, suggesting that it can be spread by water currents. The findings have important implications for our understanding of the spread of the disease and the control of the virus. The findings also have implications for the control of other diseases caused by viruses.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The population structure is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the island. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the island. They also provide a reference for the population structure of the Indian Ocean islands. Finally, they provide a reference for the population structure of the Indian Ocean islands.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While most sRNAs are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with the glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases its activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. The RNA and protein compete for the same translation site, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a mechanism that can be used to regulate the expression of genes that are important for survival in changing environments.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-SeekBar virus variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their information is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using the network of “people as sensors” to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This approach can be used to improve the efficiency of agricultural production and reduce the risk of crop failures. Our results also show that the network of “people as sensors” can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources such as water and forests.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is often assumed to be the result of a single mechanism. Here we propose a different view, where language processing is supported by a set of mechanisms that are common to many cognitive abilities. We show that the ability to integrate information into working memory can be supported by a combination of synaptic and intrinsic plasticity. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. We also show that it enables the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The soil is the largest terrestrial carbon pool, and its respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle. Despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to experimental warming remains unclear. Our analysis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming, reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with experimental warming in most biomes. This lack of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming is consistent with the results from multiple single-site studies, suggesting that the global warming signal may be masked by the inherent variability of soil respiration. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the temperature response of soil respiration in a wide range of biomes, as this information is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to model, because the process is not reversible. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is also a major evolutionary event, which has a measurable signature in the genome. We show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings suggest that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is a major evolutionary event, which has a measurable signature in the genome.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work highlights the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” is a significant milestone in the history of quasicrystals. The discovery of this material, which is a Si–Cu–Fe–Ca alloy, provides a link between the discovery of the first naturally occurring quasicrystal in the Khatyrka meteorite and the discovery of the first anthropogenic quasicrystal in the Trinity test.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” is the most enigmatic step in this pathway. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, as the cyclase, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria use a diiron protein, AcsF. The latter is a subunit of the diiron protein, and the former is a cyclase. Here, we show that the diiron protein is the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known to be associated with the development of the disease. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most severe in the state’s history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades because of the combined effects of warming temperatures and increased dryness in the winter. Our results suggest that the probability of drought will continue to increase in the future, even if global warming is limited to 2 °C.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. It also provides a general principle for understanding the function of other genes that have a similar phenotype. This principle may be applicable to other complex disorders.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present in a wide range of countries around the world. However, the results also show that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable, and that there is reason to question the conventional wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In the absence of functional mutations in the channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1, patients suffer from severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in ORAI1 that cause Stormorken syndrome, a rare disorder of hematopoiesis and skeletal muscle. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the release of aggregates from the cell of origin. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and the development of therapeutic strategies to limit the spread of aggregates and the resulting disease pathology.

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is believed to be a key factor in the maintenance of the bat–virus coevolutionary process. However, the mechanisms underlying the immune privilege of bats are not fully understood. Here, we identified a unique immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in the bat salivary gland, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular gland. MTX is a potent immunomodulator that selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential explanation for the lack of bat–virus spillover events in the past. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, there are two SHMT isozymes, one in the cytosol and one in the mitochondria. Here we show that the mitochondrial isozyme is essential for cancer cell growth, and that small-molecule inhibition of the enzyme blocks tumor growth. We also show that cancer cells have a unique metabolic vulnerability to SHMT inhibition, which is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in the brains of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that the disease is caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This metastable state is likely to be the result of a progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, which is a unique feature of this disease.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V sequences from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. The rate of global mean sea level rise is one of the most important indicators of climate change. The rate is also a key parameter in the assessment of the impact of climate change on coastal infrastructure and communities. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is based on a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data. The results are in good agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and it raises questions about the future of healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the location of the hydrogen atoms in the active site. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding the mechanism of the enzyme.

The development of a treatment for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) coronavirus infection is urgent, given the high mortality and the lack of a licensed treatment. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a symbiosis. We also show that the provision of this glycan is restricted to a specific time of day, which is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. Finally, we show that the glycan must be catabolized by the symbiont in order to maintain the acidification of the host epithelium, which is required for the host to benefit from the symbiont’s bioluminescence. This study provides a mechanism by which the provision of a single glycan can regulate the activities of a microbial community in a host. This may be a common feature of symbioses in which the host and symbiont have evolved to interact in this way. (Show more)

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested whether teachers could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. We found that teachers could be persuaded to do so, and that this change in mindset was associated with a reduction in student suspensions. This work has implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans, and the cause of this disease is the focus of intense study. To better understand the process of virus entry into cells, we engineered MERS-CoV to resist proteolysis during cell entry. This modification severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with MERS-CoV infection into human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures, which are relevant to lung infection. The more rigid uncleaved viruses were less infectious to these cell types because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and the food choices of the global population are a key driver of this problem. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.5%. This is a large effect, and it is robust to the fact that the proportion of vegetarian meals was not increased at other mealtimes. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. This is an important step toward achieving more sustainable diets.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment, and is therefore a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line expressing oncogenes that are the most common drivers of breast cancer. We find that each oncogene has a distinct surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We also find that the oncogenes depend on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling, and that this dependence is reflected in the surfaceome and glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral consequences. This is an important finding for election administration experts and policymakers alike.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to activation of astrocytes, which in turn release endothelin-1 (ET-1), which causes edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of functional vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the generation of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. Furthermore, the formation of vascular networks using ETV2-induced ECs provides a new approach for the treatment of ischemic disorders. This study may also provide a new approach for the generation of vascular networks for the regeneration of damaged organs. These findings may lead to the development of new therapies for ischemic disorders and the regeneration of damaged organs. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we demonstrate that zebrafish possess three augmentor genes, which are essential for the development of the iridophores, the pigment-producing cells of the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a unique model system to study the function of RTKs and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been extensively studied. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A virus and may help in the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. En face analysis of mouse arteries demonstrated an increased nuclear localization of YAP/TAZ and elevated levels of the target genes in the endothelium in atheroprone areas compared with athero-protective areas. YAP/TAZ activation is sufficient to promote EC proliferation and inflammation. In addition, treatment with

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. This work highlights the need for a more holistic approach to wildfire management that considers the role of humans in increasing the fire niche. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 to 15 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly approach to pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The findings may also be useful for the development of new natural repellents. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but the recent availability of a nonhuman primate model has allowed for the development of a mathematical model of the infection. The model is used to estimate the basic reproductive number, the rate of viral production, and the time to peak viral load. The model also allows for the assessment of the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of the virus. The results of the model can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of potential antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, ultimately leading to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This is of particular relevance for the development of effective management strategies for coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. In the absence of tumors, the epithelium regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. Here, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between intestinal tumors, the microbiome, and host lifespan. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cancer and aging. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the most common cause of cancer death. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of breast cancer cells that have enhanced features of cancer stemness, which may contribute to the development of resistance to chemotherapy and the emergence of metastatic disease. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, inhibit the metastatic potential of breast cancer cells, and improve the efficacy of chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this attribution is based on a single paleoclimate proxy. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation was preceded by a volcanic eruption of a small, little-known volcano in West Antarctica, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate. This finding has implications for the attribution of past climate changes. It also suggests that the recovery from the Mount Takahe eruptions may have been slower than expected, with consequences for the timing of the recovery of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. The Mount Takahe eruptions are the most distant volcanic eruptions known to have caused stratospheric ozone depletion.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, many of whom are poor and undernourished. This highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from the impacts of overfishing and other threats. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries management should be prioritized to protect food security and biodiversity. This will be particularly important in the face of climate change, which is expected to increase the frequency of extreme weather events and the risk of flooding.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles.
