The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery is important because it provides a platform for the discovery of novel genes that regulate the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, the observation that this form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity suggests that it may be a powerful platform for the study of endogenous plasticity in the adult nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is essential for the evolution of new genetic material, but the details of its spatial organization remain poorly understood. Here, we describe the spatial organization of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions experiencing intense recombination, while others are cold. The distribution of recombination rates is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the organization of recombination in plants may be similar to that in animals.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis suggests that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each with its own characteristic pattern of activity. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been difficult to interpret because of the large number of networks that have been identified. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate a small number of reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, the subordinate RSNs were activated during task performance.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. The 5′ cap structure is also found on a subset of nuclear-encoded mitochondrial mRNAs. The 5′ cap structure is thought to be produced by a single RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. We show that a second RNA polymerase also produces a 5′ cap structure on a subset of nuclear-encoded mitochondrial mRNAs. This second polymerase is not the same as the one that produces the 5′ cap structure on nuclear mRNAs. The 5′ cap structure on mitochondrial mRNAs is not the same as the 5′ cap structure on nuclear mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with metabolic memory. These epigenetic alterations persist for several years after the end of the DCCT. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms of metabolic memory and to develop new therapeutic strategies to improve the long-term control of diabetes.

The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in breast cancer has been studied extensively, but the role of FSIP1 in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the changes in the gut barrier. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is unclear. Here, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and the potential for improving their content. This knowledge will be important for the development of improved varieties of tomato with enhanced flavor. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changed as temperatures deviated from ambient conditions. This change in the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning was driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species, which affected the diversity of species that could maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on biodiversity in the context of the entire diversity–functioning relationship. This will be critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning and services.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key region for navigation. It contains a variety of neurons that encode information about the location and direction of travel. The precise organization of these neurons is not known. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the organization of neurons encoding information about the direction of travel is different from that of other types of neurons. This work provides a detailed view of the organization of neurons encoding information about the direction of travel in the MEC. It will help us understand how the brain encodes information about the location and direction of travel. It will also help us understand how the brain adapts its representation of the environment to the task at hand.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host plant and the dodder, and that FTs are able to move between the host and the dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that the FT gene in dodder C. australis does not function in flowering induction. This is likely due to the fact that the dodder has lost the ability to synthesize FT.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This is a fundamental question in social science, and our findings suggest that it may be a question with a simple answer.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cells that are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a small region of the heart, and its function is tightly regulated to maintain a normal heart rate. We have identified a key regulator of the SAN that is involved in the control of heart rate. This study reveals that the function of the SAN is linked to the content of calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of the cells of the SAN. This study also identifies a mechanism by which calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of the SAN is regulated. This mechanism may be important for the control of heart rate. This study may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. In this study, we demonstrate that Si priming of rice plants against insect attack is associated with an increase in jasmonic acid (JA) levels, which in turn enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder. Our results suggest that Si priming of plants may be a promising strategy for enhancing plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study also provides insights into the mechanism of how Si may be used as a biopesticide to control insect pests. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is often assumed to be the result of a single mechanism. Here we propose a different view, where language processing is supported by a set of mechanisms that are common to many cognitive abilities. We show that the ability to integrate information into working memory can be supported by a combination of synaptic and intrinsic plasticity. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biology. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNA is particularly challenging because of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver RNA across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of RNA across the cell wall. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities. (Show more)

The impacts of nutrient loading on the world’s lakes and rivers are well documented, but the role of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs is often overlooked. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to Lake Michigan comes from a small number of large tributaries, but that the vast majority of the nutrients delivered by small tributaries are in the dissolved form, which is more bioavailable to algae. This work highlights the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient loading and the need to address them in nutrient management strategies. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work also highlights the need to better understand the role of dams in altering the flow of nutrients and energy through watersheds. Our results suggest that the removal of dams may be a promising strategy for reducing coastal nutrient loading. (Show more)

The study of the dynamics of complex chemical networks is a central problem in the field of chemical biology. In this article, we study the dynamics of a simple model of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is difficult to access. We find that the dynamics of the network are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This finding may have implications for the design of synthetic chemical networks that are able to absorb work from their environment.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic properties of the brain, which can then predispose to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs, which may help to explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. This work also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of encephalitis on brain dynamics. This framework may also be applicable to other disorders of the brain.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the lack of long-term records of carbon isotopes and uranium isotopes. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. The event is a key example of how the Earth system can respond to abrupt climate change.

The palm oil industry is the most rapidly expanding agricultural sector in the tropics, and the vast majority of palm oil is produced in Indonesia. The industry is responsible for substantial tropical forest loss, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, of which the EXO70 subunit is the most important. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved in plants and animals, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent and the sex of the parent’s parent. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, the sex of the parent’s parent, and the sex of the parent’s great-great-great-grandparent. This paper shows that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple sex determination loci can provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating products of the metabolism of the vitamin A aldehyde, retinyl palmitate. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are products of the metabolism of the vitamin A aldehyde, retinyl palmitate. We show that the accumulation of bisretinoids in the retina is reduced in mice with reduced levels of iron, which is a cofactor for the metabolism of the vitamin A aldehyde, retinyl palmitate. These findings suggest that iron may be a factor in the metabolism of the vitamin A aldehyde, retinyl palmitate, and that iron may be a target for the development of therapies to reduce the accumulation of bisretinoids in the retina. This work also demonstrates the utility of the mouse retina as a model for the study of the metabolism of the vitamin A aldehyde, retinyl palmitate. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators has been shaped by the diversification of prey types. We also show that the evolution of specialized predators is not a dead end, and that they can evolve into generalists. These findings help us understand the evolution of specialization in predators, and how it has shaped the structure of present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution, and the study of the earliest stages of this evolution is of particular interest. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand and suggests that it arose in the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, there are two SHMT isozymes, one in the cytosol and one in the mitochondria. Here we show that the mitochondrial isozyme is essential for cancer cell growth, and that a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme blocks tumor growth in mice. We also show that cancer cells have a unique metabolic vulnerability to SHMT inhibition, which is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing body of evidence showing that the prevalence of undernutrition is declining, while the prevalence of overweight and obesity is increasing. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, which is a significant concern given that diets are a key driver of deforestation. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in strategies to improve food and nutrition security.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but the increase in weight of farm vehicles has also increased the risk of subsoil compaction. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over the last century, with the risk of compaction now exceeding that of the most severe cases of subsoil compaction observed in the last 5,000 y. This alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest sauropods had the smallest gaits, suggesting that the slow pace of sauropods may have reduced the risk of subsoil compaction. This study highlights the need to consider the ecological context of farm machinery design. (Show more)
